Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation2: The mentee has a small question about terminology that isn't blocking their work.
Story: I stood at the edge of the skate park, watching my younger brother strap on his helmet, his eyes fixed on the steep, cracked ramp. He grinned at me, excitement radiating from him as he prepared to try a trick he’d only watched online. My heart pounded with worry—I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t get hurt. But my phone buzzed in my pocket, a reminder from my mentor to check in if I had any questions. I did have a small one, something about terminology in the project I was working on, but it wasn’t urgent. Still, I knew my mentor expected me to communicate openly, not let things pile up. I glanced between my brother, who was already rolling toward the ramp, and my phone, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in. Should I run to stop him, or quickly send my question before I forgot? The pressure of being a good sibling and a responsible mentee twisted inside me, and I felt frozen, torn between two worlds that suddenly seemed impossible to balance.
